conclusion: To determine the ratio \(\frac{\varepsilon'}{\varepsilon}\), analyze the induced emf in both configurations of the rod.
For the straight rod moving perpendicularly to the magnetic field \(\mathbf{B}\), the induced emf \(\varepsilon\) is given by the motional emf formula \(\varepsilon = B \cdot L \cdot v\).
\(B\) is the magnetic field strength, \(L\) is the length of the rod, \(v\) is the velocity of the rod.
When the rod is bent into two equal-length segments at a right angle and placed in the magnetic field, each segment has a length \(L/2\).
The rod moves along the angle bisector with velocity \(v\).
The velocity \(v\) can be resolved into two perpendicular components along each segment, each component is \(v/\sqrt{2}\).
The induced emf in each segment is \(\varepsilon_{\text{segment}} = B \cdot \left(\frac{L}{2}\right) \cdot \left(\frac{v}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\).

The total induced emf \(\varepsilon'\) is \(2 \cdot \varepsilon_{\text{segment}} = 2 \cdot B \cdot \left(\frac{L}{2}\right) \cdot \left(\frac{v}{\sqrt{2}}\right) = B \cdot L \cdot v \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\).
Calculate the ratio \(\frac{\varepsilon'}{\varepsilon} = \frac{B \cdot L \cdot v \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}{B \cdot L \cdot v} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\).
